channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2025 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Quantum computing ‘KPIs’ could distinguish true breakthroughs from spurious claims
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04063-8

Researchers are devising ways to make new machines face off, without the hype.
item.dc:title: Quantum computing ‘KPIs’ could distinguish true breakthroughs from spurious claims
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Gibney

item.title: Solar cells that combine multiple perovskite layers surpass 30% efficiency
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03806-x

Perovskites are promising materials for solar cells. A layer of dipolar molecules at the perovskite surface improves the efficiency of these devices.
item.dc:title: Solar cells that combine multiple perovskite layers surpass 30% efficiency
item.dc:creator: Shuaifeng Hu
Henry J. Snaith

item.title: Quantifying grain boundary deformation mechanisms in small-grained metals
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09800-7

Experimental observations in small-grained polycrystals suggest a new concept of considering metallic grain boundaries not as defects but as separate defect-containing lattices, providing a potential explanation for the deformation behaviour of nanocrystalline metals.
item.dc:title: Quantifying grain boundary deformation mechanisms in small-grained metals
item.dc:creator: Romain Gautier
Frédéric Mompiou
Oliver Renk
Christophe Coupeau
Nicolas Combe
Gregory Seine
Marc Legros

item.title: Laser-based conversion electron Mössbauer spectroscopy of <sup>229</sup>ThO<sub>2</sub>
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09776-4

Laser-induced conversion electron Mössbauer spectroscopy, which detects electrons emitted by 229Th nuclei in a thin ThO2 sample excited by vacuum ultraviolet light, is demonstrated, opening the possibility of a conversion-electron-based nuclear clock.
item.dc:title: Laser-based conversion electron Mössbauer spectroscopy of <sup>229</sup>ThO<sub>2</sub>
item.dc:creator: Ricky Elwell
James E. S. Terhune
Christian Schneider
Harry W. T. Morgan
Hoang Bao Tran Tan
Udeshika C. Perera
Daniel A. Rehn
Marisa C. Alfonso
Lars von der Wense
Benedict Seiferle
Kevin Scharl
Peter G. Thirolf
Andrei Derevianko
Eric R. Hudson

item.title: A simple slipknot for precise force control
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03829-4

The tension of conventional surgical sutures can affect wound healing and is dependent on the surgeon’s experience. Imaging and simulations reveal that slipknots can reproducibly store and release force, enabling precise and consistent surgical knotting without the need for electronic sensors or specialized equipment.
item.dc:title: A simple slipknot for precise force control

item.title: Nuclear clocks could use electrical signals to keep time
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03732-y

The emission of photons by excited nuclei has been explored for timekeeping and sensing, but nuclear processes that eject electrons offer practical advantages.
item.dc:title: Nuclear clocks could use electrical signals to keep time
item.dc:creator: Xiwen Zhang
Olga Kocharovskaya
